substeps.title: Look for early signs
substeps.description:
Check the skin around your IV site every day. Look for:
• Redness
• Swelling
• Warmth
• Pain or tenderness
• Discharge or fluid
substeps.moreInfo: These can be early signs of irritation, infection, or phlebitis. Contact your nurse if you see any of them.

substeps.title: Feel the area
substeps.description: Gently press around the IV site to check for warmth or discomfort.
substeps.moreInfo: Warm, tender areas could signal inflammation or infection — even if they look normal at first.

substeps.title: Check line position
substeps.description: Make sure your IV line hasn’t moved. If the tubing outside your arm looks longer than usual, stop using it and contact your nurse.
substeps.moreInfo: Movement of the line can cause irritation or make it unsafe to use.

substeps.title: Call your clinic immediately if:
substeps.description:
• You notice spreading redness or swelling
• There is pus or fluid around the site
• You feel increasing pain or heat
• The dressing is wet or loose
substeps.moreInfo: These could be signs of infection. Do not use the line until it’s been checked.

substeps.title: Call 112 or seek urgent care if:
substeps.description:
• You have a high fever or chills
• You feel faint, confused, or short of breath
• There is rapid swelling or severe pain
• You suspect sepsis or a severe allergic reaction
substeps.moreInfo: These are emergency symptoms. Tell them you are receiving IV treatment at home.

substeps.title: Check before every infusion
substeps.description: Always check the site before connecting anything. If there is redness, swelling, or tenderness, do not proceed.
substeps.moreInfo: Using the line when inflamed can make problems worse or introduce infection.

substeps.title: Stop immediately if:
substeps.description:
• You feel burning or stinging
• You see swelling or leakage during the infusion
• The infusion is not flowing as expected
substeps.moreInfo: These could signal infiltration (fluid leaking into tissue) or a blocked or dislodged line.
